content: so about the one millionth person to do
this but nonetheless for sake of completeness this is how I do giant
crystals I use these as show pieces from my Necron tomb worlds but you could
easily with a different color selection use it you and your D&D campaign blue
and purple for the Underdark red orange for the elemental plane of
fire you get the idea stick around at the end I'll show you a
few in context examples I do use a hot wire cutter and an airbrush but in case
you don't have one or both of those tools I'm going to show you how to do it
with just a plain crafting knife and with a plain old brush will be using
extruded polystyrene or home insulation to make the crystals I use 1 inch thick
for the larger ones I actually want it to be 2 inches thick so either buy some
of that or make it yourself like this some white PVA glue spread it out for
full coverage and stick together place a book or something on it leave it to dry
overnight so first cut a rectangular shaped piece
like this then slice off two opposing corners if you use a knife make sure you
have a relatively fresh blade and don't just push it down draw it back and forth
in order to get a nice clean cut then go at one end from an extreme angle
like this flip it over and take off some more I usually do four or five strikes
to form the tip of the crystal as for the bottom if you cut it
perpendicularly it's going to point straight upwards when we mount it on the
base that's kind of boring so cut it at a bit of an angle instead of course if
you have a hot wire cutter like the proxxon table I highly recommend you use
that both for ease and for cleanliness of cuts now as for the base
these are cork sheets a quarter inch thick and I think there are 12 inches
square you can find a bit most any crafting store they're very flimsy we'll
address that in a moment dry fit your crystals to get a general
idea of the shape draw out the boundary and then begin tearing it out by tearing
you get a nice jagged rocky natural-looking edge onto my favorite
material chipboard this is graphics medium chipboard very
sturdy trace the shape onto it then cut it out and attach it to the cork with
any kind of glue will work but I use hot glue because strong and fast
now the bass is nice and rigid attach the crystals again I used hot glue
flock the bass cover it with white PVA glue and try and focus the larger
aggregate around the base of the crystals and then find sand everywhere
else once it's totally dry mix up some white
glue and water about fifty-fifty in a spray bottle and hit the entire piece
this is gonna help secure those larger pebbles as well as any loose sand not
going to do this on camera cuz it's really messy go outside and do it this
will take a solid day to dry make sure you let it become totally bone-dry paint
I'm doing green crystals but whatever you choose apply a dark version of that
color to the crystals as a base coat with cheap acrylic craft paint you'll
probably need two coats for the ground black again probably need two coats next
apply an over brush of dark grey to the base this is heavier than a dry brush
but lighter than a base coat aim for like 80% coverage then dry brush with a
plain grey to make all that detail pop as for the crystals let's pause for a
moment first I'll show you how to do this with a brush and then I'll go back
and show you how to do it with an airbrush take your medium green and
basically do a heavy dry brush with it the direction of the brushstrokes is
what matters here begin at an edge with a brush angled and then whip it
backwards so that the tip is away from the piece by the time it reaches the
center it's easier to just watch what I'm doing here than to try and describe
it the intended effect is that you have a gradient dark green in the center of a
face moving to lighter at the edges and take a lighter green and pretty much
repeat that process but this time a little bit less this further helps the
gradient lastly edge highlight with a very light
color in this case I'm actually using yellow to help intensify the glowing but
you could just as easily mix some white with one of your middle tones to get a
highlight color all right so here's the same idea but
done with an airbrush medium green along the edges giving it some pretty strong
trigger action and be sure to hit the ground around the crystal and lighter
green again along the edges but with less flow and again hit the ground but
with a smaller radius and then same as before edge highlight with a brush and
don't forget to dry brush that final color on the glow on the ground and
before we go to the table I'd like to take a moment to draw your attention to
hero's hoard which is an excellent resource for 3d printed scenery
including but not limited to Altru tiles products so if you're into 3d printing
even if it's just to supplement your conventional crafting it is worth a
click to check it out and see what's what so here's four pieces that I made
being used to show off my nekron army kind of got tired of fighting on
Imperial worlds more buildings so wanted to do something weird and this fit the
bill perfectly I use the same paints same brand same colors and everything as
I used on the models just to help with coherency and I think that kind of shows
here I've wanted to do crystals for a long time I had tried chipboard so I'd
modelled them in 3ds max and then unfolded them and then printed a
template those were smoother but really hard to
produce this ended up being a lot quicker and here it is in use with some
tiles these are the cavern tiles from episode 28 and if you like the
miniatures check out episode 9 or livestream number 2 so you can see it
just sits right there on top of the tiles looks very alien in that setting
definitely a good centerpiece for some kind of weird encounter or puzzle and
here they are in a grid list set up being used to define the boundaries of
the cave or whatever the parties in so you can see pretty versatile pieces
like so much of what we do really live ins up the table love the glow effect I
am why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
